metadata.titleEn: Ground observation dataset of corn biomass, vegetation coverage, leaf area index and plant height at Daman station in the middle reaches of Heihe River (growth period in 2017)
metadata.description: This dataset is a continuous ground observation data of vegetation coverage (%), biomass (g/plant), leaf area index (LAI) and plant height (cm) of seed corn during the growing period in 2017 at Daman Station ( 38.85551N,100.37223E)in the middle reaches of the Heihe River. Ground observation was carried out in three sample plots.  Biomass observation included fresh and dry aboveground biomass, fresh and dry underground biomass (fresh and dry root weight), vegetation coverage was observed by digital camera, leaf area index was observed by LAI 2200, and plant height was observed by tape measure. The observation period was from May 15 to September 21, 2017, in which LAI started from June 6. Observation parameters were observed every 5 days before July 31 and every 10 days thereafter, and a total of 21 observations (LAI was 17) were carried out during the whole growing period. The dataset can provide data basis for inversion and validation of surface vegetation parameters.
metadata.instructions: Observation data are stored in Excel form. The file name is yyyy.xlsm, where yyyy stands for year.

background: Crop biomass is one of the most important biophysical indicators of crop growth. The accurate and efficient estimation of the regional crop biomass at different growth stages is of great importance in guiding crop management decision making, such as in effective fertilization, water irrigation, weeding, and pest and disease management. In addition, as an important aspect of biomass energy, the accurate estimation of crop biomass contributes to the rational and effective utilization of biomass energy. Moreover, effective estimates of crop biomass during the growing season could play a key role in crop yield prediction. The traditional crop biomass estimation method is mainly based on field measurements, which include destructive field sampling, laboratory drying and weighting. The traditional methods are relatively accurate, but they are labor intensive and time consuming. Moreover, the sparse nature of space makes it impossible to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales. Thus, it is impossible to acquire the regional crop biomass via ground measurements alone. The satellite remote sensing technique is a unique and useful method for crop biomass monitoring in a repeatable manner due to the valuable information it provides on vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage and long time series, which effectively compensates for the deficiency of traditional biomass estimation methods. Previous studies have revealed that remote sensing is a reliable and effective technique to obtain biophysical and biochemical crop information.
research objective: In this paper, four machine learning models, namely random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), artificial neural network (ANN), and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) were adopted to estimate the seasonal corn biomass based on field observation data and moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) reflectance data from 2012 to 2019 in the middle reaches of the Heihe River basin, China.
challenges: This is currently one of the major challenges for agricultural researchers and farm managers.
methods: In this study, the corn biomass was estimated based on daily MODIS datasets with a 500 m spatial resolution combined with long-term ground observation data in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin, and four machine learning algorithms, namely RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost, were adopted to predict the biomass. Large, relatively homogeneous areas, which mainly functioned as corn growing areas, were selected as the sample sites. According to a field survey of the sample sites, a total of sixteen sites were selected in 2012, and three sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019. One to three plots for each sample site were chosen for further biomass observation, with each plot covering an area of 100 m ×100 m. All selected plants in each plot were collected, and the roots of the corn plants were washed. The fresh weight was measured, after which the plants were transported to the laboratory, chopped into easy-to-dry segments, and dried in an oven at 85°C for 48–72 h until a constant dry biomass was obtained. MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019 were analyzed in this study. The forward feature selection method was implemented to choose the most influential variables, which is an iterative method starting from the condition of no model features. In each iteration, we add a given feature that best improves the model until the addition of a new variable does not further improve the model performance. The RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost algorithms were adopted in this study. R software was used to implement the above four machine learning algorithms with the randomForest, kernlab, brnn, and xgboost packages. In this study, the caret package in R software was applied to tune the parameters of the above four machine learning algorithms. The 10-fold cross validation method was implemented to evaluate the performance of the above four machine learning models due to the small number of training samples.
dataset: MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019 were analyzed in this study. A total of sixteen sites were selected in 2012, and three sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019. One to three plots for each sample site were chosen for further biomass observation, with each plot covering an area of 100 m ×100 m.
findings: The results indicated that the corn biomass was suitably estimated (the coefficient of determination (R2) was between 0.72 and 0.78) with the four machine learning models. The XGBoost model performed better than the other three models (R2 = 0.78, root mean squared error (RMSE) = 2.86 t/ha and mean absolute error (MAE) = 1.86 t/ha). Moreover, the RF model was an effective method (R2 = 0.77, RMSE = 2.91 t/ha and MAE = 1.91 t/ha), with a performance comparable to that of the XGBoost model.

Disjunctive.Question: Which dataset is more commonly used for analyzing crop biomass, MODIS MCD43A4, MOD15A2, or another dataset?

Concept Completion.Question: Where were the sample sites for corn biomass observation located, and how were they selected?
Concept Completion.Answer: Middle reaches of the Heihe River basin, China

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to estimate crop biomass that integrates both ground measurements and remote sensing data?
Example.Answer: A data collection method for estimating crop biomass involves using field observation data along with moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) reflectance data. Ground measurements include collecting plant samples from designated plots, measuring fresh weight, and obtaining dry biomass after laboratory processing. This is complemented by analyzing MODIS products to enhance spatial coverage and temporal resolution.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset used in machine learning models to estimate crop biomass and describe its components?
Example.Answer: The dataset used in machine learning models for estimating crop biomass includes MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products, analyzed from May to September over several years. This dataset is combined with long-term ground observation data from selected sites where field measurements are conducted, including biomass observations from plots covering large homogeneous areas.

Feature Specification.Question: What specific features are considered when selecting sample sites for crop biomass estimation using remote sensing?
Feature Specification.Answer: large, relatively homogeneous areas, corn growing areas, 100 m × 100 m plots

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'biomass estimation' in the context of corn crop monitoring?
Definition.Answer: Biomass estimation in the context of corn crop monitoring refers to the process of assessing the amount of biological material, both above and below ground, present in corn plants. It involves measuring parameters such as fresh and dry weight of the crop, which can be used to infer crop growth stages, health, and yield potential. Traditionally, this involves field measurements that include destructive sampling and laboratory analysis, but remote sensing techniques are also employed to estimate biomass over larger areas and longer time series.

Definition.Question: What does 'feature selection' refer to in the context of machine learning models for biomass prediction?
Definition.Answer: Feature selection in the context of machine learning models for biomass prediction refers to the process of selecting the most relevant variables that contribute to the model's predictive accuracy. It involves identifying which input features, such as spectral data from satellite imagery, have the most significant impact on estimating biomass. The forward feature selection method, for instance, iteratively adds features to the model and evaluates their impact, enhancing the model's performance by including only the most influential variables.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for estimating corn biomass using ground observation compare to satellite remote sensing techniques in terms of accuracy and efficiency?
Comparison.Answer: Ground observation methods for estimating corn biomass are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming, involving destructive field sampling and laboratory processing. In contrast, satellite remote sensing techniques provide valuable information on vegetation parameters with high spatial coverage and long time series, offering a unique and efficient method for regional biomass estimation that compensates for the limitations of traditional ground-based methods.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the application of machine learning models, such as RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost, for estimating corn biomass compared to traditional field measurement methods?
Comparison.Answer: Machine learning models like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost rely on combining satellite data such as MODIS reflectance with ground observations to estimate corn biomass, offering a scalable solution with high accuracy. Traditional field measurement methods focus on direct, destructive sampling, which is accurate but not scalable for large areas. The machine learning models, especially XGBoost, showed high performance in biomass estimation with high R2 values, making them suitable for regional assessments.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges faced by agricultural researchers in using traditional biomass estimation methods compare to those encountered when utilizing remote sensing and machine learning approaches?
Comparison.Answer: Traditional biomass estimation methods face challenges of being labor-intensive, time-consuming, and limited in spatial scope, which restricts their applicability for large-scale regional analysis. In contrast, remote sensing and machine learning approaches address these challenges by providing efficient, scalable, and repeatable biomass monitoring solutions, though they require sophisticated data processing and model training to accurately interpret satellite data for biomass estimation.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of ground observation data with remote sensing data improve the accuracy of biomass estimation models in agricultural research?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of ground observation data with remote sensing data, such as MODIS reflectance data, allows for the use of machine learning models to estimate biomass with greater accuracy. The combination of detailed ground observations and the spatial and temporal coverage of remote sensing data addresses the limitations of traditional field measurements, providing a comprehensive understanding of biomass distribution across larger areas.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can machine learning models be optimized to enhance the prediction of crop biomass using remote sensing data?
Interpretation.Answer: Machine learning models can be optimized through techniques such as forward feature selection to identify influential variables, tuning of model parameters using software packages like R, and employing cross-validation methods such as 10-fold cross-validation to assess model performance. These approaches help refine model accuracy and reliability in predicting crop biomass from remote sensing data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the reliance on traditional field measurement methods for crop biomass estimation in agricultural research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Traditional field measurement methods are commonly used because they are relatively accurate in estimating crop biomass. These methods involve direct measurements, such as destructive field sampling, laboratory drying, and weighing, which provide precise data on biomass. However, they are labor-intensive and time-consuming, making them less feasible for large-scale or regional analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do researchers face challenges when attempting to estimate regional crop biomass using ground measurements alone?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Ground measurements alone are challenging for regional crop biomass estimation due to their sparse nature in space, which makes it impossible to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales. These methods are labor-intensive and time-consuming, thus limiting their applicability for acquiring large-scale biomass data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What has driven the adoption of satellite remote sensing techniques in monitoring crop biomass?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Satellite remote sensing techniques are increasingly adopted for monitoring crop biomass because they offer valuable information on vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage, and long time series data. These techniques provide a repeatable and efficient method for biomass estimation, effectively compensating for the limitations of traditional ground measurement methods.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing satellite remote sensing data for crop biomass monitoring compared to traditional field measurement methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing satellite remote sensing data for crop biomass monitoring allows for a more comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales due to its high spatial coverage and long time series. This method compensates for the labor-intensive and time-consuming nature of traditional methods, which are limited by sparse spatial coverage. Remote sensing also provides valuable information on vegetation parameters, making it a unique and useful method for repeatable crop biomass monitoring.

Causal Consequence.Question: If machine learning models like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost are applied to field observation data combined with MODIS reflectance data, what are the likely outcomes in terms of biomass estimation accuracy?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The application of machine learning models such as RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost to field observation data combined with MODIS reflectance data is likely to result in suitable corn biomass estimation, with the coefficient of determination (R2) ranging between 0.72 and 0.78. The XGBoost model may perform better than the other models, achieving an R2 of 0.78, indicating a high level of accuracy in biomass estimation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the possible effects of implementing a 10-fold cross-validation method when evaluating machine learning models due to a small number of training samples?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing a 10-fold cross-validation method when evaluating machine learning models can enhance model performance reliability and accuracy in scenarios with a small number of training samples. This method allows for a thorough assessment of model robustness by using the data more efficiently, which helps prevent overfitting and provides a better generalization of the model's predictive capabilities.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific methods used for collecting ground observation data of corn biomass, vegetation coverage, leaf area index, and plant height during the growing season?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Ground observation data of corn biomass is collected by measuring above-ground and below-ground biomass, both fresh and dry weight. Vegetation coverage is observed using the digital camera method, leaf area index (LAI) is measured with the LAI 2200 instrument, and plant height is measured using a tape measure.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the accurate collection of crop biomass data at different growth stages in the middle reaches of river basins?
Enablement.Answer: Methods such as field measurements, including destructive field sampling, laboratory drying, and weighting, enable the accurate collection of crop biomass data. Additionally, the integration of satellite remote sensing techniques, specifically MODIS reflectance data, can provide valuable information on vegetation parameters, which enhances the estimation of crop biomass.

Enablement.Question: How do specific technological tools enable the monitoring of vegetation parameters for crop biomass estimation?
Enablement.Answer: Technological tools such as the LAI 2200 for leaf area index measurement and digital cameras for vegetation coverage observation enable the monitoring of vegetation parameters. These tools provide precise ground observation data that can be used alongside remote sensing data to enhance crop biomass estimation.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and resources enable the effective use of machine learning models for estimating crop biomass using remote sensing data?
Enablement.Answer: The availability of long-term ground observation data and MODIS datasets from multiple years provides foundational resources for training machine learning models. The implementation of algorithms like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost, along with tuning through R software, further enables the effective use of these models in estimating crop biomass.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional field measurement methods struggle to provide comprehensive data coverage at larger scales for crop biomass estimation?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional field measurement methods are labor-intensive and time-consuming, making it difficult to cover larger scales comprehensively. The sparse nature of space also limits the ability to provide a thorough understanding at regional or larger scales through ground measurements alone.

Expectation.Question: Why is the accurate and efficient estimation of regional crop biomass at different growth stages considered crucial for agricultural management?
Expectation.Answer: Accurate and efficient estimation of regional crop biomass at different growth stages is crucial for agricultural management because it guides decision-making in areas such as fertilization, water irrigation, weeding, and pest and disease management. It also contributes to the rational utilization of biomass energy and plays a key role in predicting crop yields.

Judgmental.Question: What is your perspective on the challenges faced in selecting the most influential variables for machine learning models when predicting crop biomass, particularly with limited ground observation data?
Judgmental.Answer: Selecting the most influential variables for machine learning models in predicting crop biomass is challenging due to the limited number of ground observation data points, which necessitates careful feature selection to avoid overfitting. The forward feature selection method can help identify the most impactful variables, but the process requires iterative testing and validation to ensure model performance is optimized. This challenge highlights the importance of balancing complexity and interpretability in model development.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how different data collection methods can accurately estimate crop biomass at a regional scale.
Assertion.Answer: Traditional methods involve destructive field sampling, which are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming. Remote sensing techniques, like using satellite data, provide valuable information on vegetation parameters with high spatial coverage and long time series, helping to estimate crop biomass efficiently at a regional scale.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about how machine learning models can be optimized for estimating crop biomass using diverse datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Machine learning models like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost are optimized by using feature selection methods and parameter tuning. In the context of crop biomass estimation, forward feature selection is used to iteratively add the most influential variables, while the parameters are tuned using tools like the caret package in R software to improve model performance.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the challenges faced in collecting and utilizing ground observation data for biomass estimation.
Assertion.Answer: Ground observation data collection is labor-intensive and time-consuming, often involving destructive sampling and laboratory processes. Additionally, the sparse nature of field measurements makes it difficult to achieve comprehensive understanding at larger scales, which is why integration with remote sensing data is beneficial for biomass estimation.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the effectiveness of the techniques used for estimating crop biomass based on field observation data and remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The field observation methods involve detailed measurements of crop biomass, such as weighing plant material before and after drying to obtain dry biomass. Remote sensing techniques, particularly using MODIS datasets, provide a unique approach, allowing for regional scale monitoring that compensates for the limitations of ground measurements. Machine learning models like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost have been effectively used to estimate biomass, with XGBoost showing the highest performance in terms of R2 and RMSE values.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest potential strategies for improving data collection methods for crop biomass estimation in the middle reaches of the Heihe River basin.
Request/Directive.Answer: Enhancing ground observation by increasing the number of sample sites and plots could provide a more comprehensive dataset for model training. Additionally, integrating more advanced remote sensing technologies or higher resolution satellite data could improve the spatial and temporal resolution of the collected data. Developing hybrid approaches that combine ground and remote sensing data with advanced machine learning algorithms could further refine biomass estimation models.
